tit.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。

sen.j: 親王（しんのう）とは、東アジアにおいて、男性皇族に与えられる称号、又はかかる称号を有する者。
sen.e: Shinnou is the title given to the male members in an Imperial family in East Asia, or is somebody who owns the title.
Shinno is the title given to the male members in an Imperial family in East Asia, or is somebody who owns the title.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。
sen.e: Shinno is the title given to the male members in an Imperial family in East Asia, or is somebody who owns the title.

sen.j: 日本の皇族のうち親王宣下をうけた男子の皇族。
sen.e: In the Japanese Imperial family, it is the male members who has been given the title of Imperial prince.
In the Japanese Imperial family, it is the male members who has been given the title of Imperial prince.
In the Japanese Imperial family, it is the male members who has been given the title of Imperial prince.

sen.j: または、授けられた身位、称号のことを指す（親王号とも）。
sen.e: It also points to the received rank or title (otherwise known as Shinnougou)
It also means the received rank or title (otherwise known as Shinnougou)
sen.cmt: points to ⇒ means に訂正しました。
sen.e: It also means the received rank or title (otherwise known as Shinnougou)

sen.j: 清朝の皇族の最高位。
sen.e: Shinnou is the highest rank for an Imperial family of the Qing dynasty.
Shinnou is the highest rank in an Imperial family of the Qing dynasty.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。for ⇒ in に訂正しました。
sen.e: Shinnou is the highest rank in an Imperial family of the Qing dynasty.

sen.j: 正式名称は和碩親王（ホショ＝イ＝チンワン）。
sen.e: The formal name is Hosho=I=Chinwan.
The formal name is Hosho=I=Chinwan.
The formal name is Hosho=I=Chinwan.

sen.j: 大韓帝国の皇族の最高位。
sen.e: It is the highest rank for an Imperial family in the Korean Empire.
It is the highest rank in an Imperial family in the Korean Empire.
sen.cmt: for ⇒ in に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is the highest rank in an Imperial family in the Korean Empire.

tit.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 現在は天皇の嫡出の子、及び、天皇の嫡男系の嫡出の子（皇孫）で男子であるもの、また、天皇の兄弟を親王という（皇室典範6、7条参照）。
sen.e: Presently, the Emperor's legitimate sons and the sons of the Emperor's legitimate sons (Imperial grandson), along with the brothers of the Emperor are called Shinnou (Referenced Imperial House Act article 6, 7).

Presently, the Emperor's legitimate sons and the sons of the Emperor's legitimate sons (Imperial grandson), along with the brothers of the Emperor are called Shinno (Referenced Imperial House Act article 6, 7).
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。
sen.e: Presently, the Emperor's legitimate sons and the sons of the Emperor's legitimate sons (Imperial grandson), along with the brothers of the Emperor are called Shinno (Referenced Imperial House Act article 6, 7).

sen.j: なお、女性の親王号を内親王、親王でない皇族は王 (皇族)、女王 (皇族)という。
sen.e: Further, the Shinnouou for females are called Naishinnou, and the Imperial family who are not Shinnou are called king (Imperial family) or queen (Imperial family).
Further, the Shinnogo for females are called Naishinno, and the Imperial family who are not Shinno are called king (Imperial family) or queen (Imperial family).
sen.cmt: Shinnouou ⇒ Shinnogo に訂正しました。Naishinnou, Shinnou の u を削除しました。
sen.e: Further, the Shinnogo for females are called Naishinno, and the Imperial family who are not Shinno are called king (Imperial family) or queen (Imperial family).

sen.j: 現代では主に日本の皇族にのみ使われるが、外国の皇族や王族に対する呼称、プリンスの訳語の一つとしても便宜上、親王が用いられることがある。
sen.e: Presently, the term is only used mainly for the Japanese Imperial family, but is sometimes used as a name for foreign Imperial families or Royal families, or as one translation for the title Prince.

Presently, the term Shinno is only used mainly for the Japanese Imperial family, but is sometimes used as a name for foreign Imperial families or Royal families, or as one translation for the title Prince.
sen.cmt: the term ⇒ the term Shinno に訂正しました。
sen.e: Presently, the term Shinno is only used mainly for the Japanese Imperial family, but is sometimes used as a name for foreign Imperial families or Royal families, or as one translation for the title Prince.

sen.j: 皇族身位令（皇室令。既に廃止）に準じて、成年となった場合は大勲位の勲等に叙せられ、大勲位菊花大綬章が授けられる。
sen.e: Kouzoku Shinirei (Koshitsu-rei <the Imperial Families' Act.>
sen.cmt: 皇族身位令の適訳が見つからなかったので、kouzoku Shinireiとしてあります。
sen.e: In accordance with Kozoku Shinirei (Koshitsu-rei <the Imperial Families' Act.>, already abolished), when one becomes a legal adult, he is bestowed the order of supreme merit, and is given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
sen.cmt: 後列をこちらにまとめました。Kouzoku ⇒ Kozoku, the supreme order order of merit ⇒ the order of supreme merit に訂正しました。
sen.e: In accordance with Kozoku Shinirei (Koshitsu-rei <the Imperial Families' Act.>, already abolished), when one becomes a legal adult, he is bestowed the order of supreme merit, and is given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.

sen.j: なお、内親王は勲一等に叙せられ、宝冠章が授けられ、王は勲一等に叙せられ、勲一等旭日桐花大綬章が授けられ、女王 (皇族)は勲二等に叙せられ、勲二等宝冠章が授けられることになっていた。
sen.e: Further, the Imperial Princess was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Order of the Precious Crown, the King was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower, and the Queen (of Imperial family) was bestowed the Order of Second Class and received the the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony.

Further, the Imperial Princess was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Order of the Precious Crown, the King was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower, and the Queen (of Imperial family) was bestowed the Order of Second Class and received the the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony.

Further, the Imperial Princess was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Order of the Precious Crown, the King was bestowed the Order of First Class and received the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower, and the Queen (of Imperial family) was bestowed the Order of Second Class and received the the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony.

sen.j: 戦後でも親王には、大勲位菊花大綬章が授けられ、内親王、親王妃には宝冠章（現、宝冠大綬章）が、女王には勲二等宝冠章（現、宝冠牡丹章）が授けられている。
sen.e: Even after the war, the Shinnou were given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum, the Imperial Princesses were given the Order of the Precious Crown (the present Grand Cordon of the Order of the Precious Crown), and the Queens were given the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony (the present Order of the Precious Crown, Peony).

Even after the war, the Shinno was given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum, the Imperial Princesses were given the Order of the Precious Crown (the present Grand Cordon of the Order of the Precious Crown), and the Queens were given the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony (the present Order of the Precious Crown, Peony).
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。were ⇒ was,
sen.e: Even after the war, the Shinno was given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum, the Imperial Princesses were given the Order of the Precious Crown (the present Grand Cordon of the Order of the Precious Crown), and the Queens were given the Order of the Precious Crown, Peony (the present Order of the Precious Crown, Peony).

sen.j: 律令制では天皇の子、および兄弟姉妹が親王とされ、位階を授けられ、給田や俸禄が与えられて、家司（けいし）が付属せられた。
sen.e: With the Ritsuryo system, the emperor's child along with his siblings were the Shinnou, and they received Ikai (Court rank), kyuden (provided rice field) and horoku (stipend), and a Keishi (household superintendent) was attached.

With the Ritsuryo system, the emperor's child along with his siblings were the Shinno, and they received Ikai (Court rank), kyuden (provided rice field) and horoku (stipend), and a Keishi (household superintendent) was attached.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。
sen.e: With the Ritsuryo system, the emperor's child along with his siblings were the Shinno, and they received Ikai (Court rank), kyuden (provided rice field) and horoku (stipend), and a Keishi (household superintendent) was attached.

sen.j: 皇孫は二世から四世（場合によりそれ以降も）が諸王と称せられた。
sen.e: The second to the fourth generation (sometimes more) Imperial descendants were called Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation).
From the second to the fourth generations (sometimes more) of Imperial descendants were called Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation).
sen.cmt: 文頭にFromを追加しました。 generation ⇒ generations of
sen.e: From the second to the fourth generations (sometimes more) of Imperial descendants were called Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation).

sen.j: 淳仁天皇は二世王から践祚したので、それ以降は親王宣下をもって親王とする慣習となった。
sen.e: Because Emperor Junnin ascended the throne as a second generation king, it became custom to give the title of Imperial Prince to those after the second generation and make them an Imperial Prince.
Because Emperor Junnin ascended the throne as a second generation king, it became a custom to give the title of Imperial Prince to those after the second generation and make them an Imperial Prince.
Because Emperor Junnin ascended the throne as a second generation king, it became a custom to give the title of Imperial Prince to those after the second generation and make them an Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 明治以前には、たとえ天皇の子供であっても親王宣下を受けない限り親王を名乗る事は出来なかった（参考：以仁王）。
sen.e: Before Meiji, even if one was the child of an emperor, he could not announce himself as Shinnou unless if he received the title of Imperial Prince (Reference Prince Mochihito).
Before Meiji Period, even a child of an emperor could not announce himself as Shinno unless he received the title of Imperial Prince (Reference Prince Mochihito).
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。Meiji ⇒ Meiji Period, even if one was the child of an emperor, he ⇒ even a child of an emperor
sen.e: Before Meiji Period, even a child of an emperor could not announce himself as Shinno unless he received the title of Imperial Prince (Reference Prince Mochihito).

sen.j: 逆に世襲親王家の当主などの皇孫以下の世代に相当する皇族であっても、親王宣下を受けて親王となることもあった。
sen.e: On the other hand, there were cases where even an Imperial family who corresponds to younger generations than the Imperial grandchild, such as the head of a hereditary Shinnou family, would become a Shinnou by receiving the title of Imperial Prince.

On the other hand, there were cases where even an Imperial family who corresponds to younger generations than the Imperial grandchild, such as the head of a hereditary Shinno family, would become a Shinno by receiving the title of Imperial Prince.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。
sen.e: On the other hand, there were cases where even an Imperial family who corresponds to younger generations than the Imperial grandchild, such as the head of a hereditary Shinno family, would become a Shinno by receiving the title of Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 平安時代から江戸時代にかけては、律令により、親王は「一品」から「四品」までの品位 (身位)に叙せられた。
sen.e: From the Heian period to the Edo period, due to the Ritsuryo code, a Shinnou would be bestowed a honi (rank) from Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) to Shihon (Fourth Order of an Imperial Prince).

From the Heian period to the Edo period, due to the Ritsuryo code, a Shinno would be bestowed a honi (rank) from 'Ippon' (First Order of an Imperial Prince) to 'Shihon' (Fourth Order of an Imperial Prince).
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。' ' を追加しました。
sen.e: From the Heian period to the Edo period, due to the Ritsuryo code, a Shinno would be bestowed a honi (rank) from 'Ippon' (First Order of an Imperial Prince) to 'Shihon' (Fourth Order of an Imperial Prince).

sen.j: 一品を受けた親王は一品親王、品位を受けない（もしくは罪などで品位を剥奪された）親王は無品親王と呼ばれた。
sen.e: A Shinnou who received the Ippon was called Ippon Shinnou, and a Shinnou who did not receive a honi (or those whose honi was stripped because of a crime) were called Muhon-Shinno (Imperial Prince without court rank).

A Shinno who received the Ippon was called Ippon Shinno, and a Shinno who did not receive a honi (or those whose honi was stripped because of a crime) were called Muhon-Shinno (Imperial Prince without court rank).
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。
sen.e: A Shinno who received the Ippon was called Ippon Shinno, and a Shinno who did not receive a honi (or those whose honi was stripped because of a crime) were called Muhon-Shinno (Imperial Prince without court rank).

sen.j: 江戸時代以前において出家した親王を入道親王（にゅうどうしんのう）、出家後に親王宣下を受けた皇族を法親王（ほっしんのう）といった。
sen.e: A Shinnou who became a priest before the Edo period were called Nyudo Shinno, and an Imperial family who received the title of Imperial prince after they became a priest were called Cloistered Imperial Prince.

A Shinno who became a priest before the Edo period was called Nyudo Shinno, and an Imperial family who received the title of Imperial prince after they became a priest was called Cloistered Imperial Prince.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。were ⇒ was
sen.e: A Shinno who became a priest before the Edo period was called Nyudo Shinno, and an Imperial family who received the title of Imperial prince after they became a priest was called Cloistered Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 平安時代、桓武天皇の政策により東宮とならなかった親王を八省卿にする方針が打ち出されたが、後に親王に政治責任を負わせることに消極的な立場から中務省、兵部省兵部省 (律令制)、式部省、弾正尹、大宰帥といった名誉職に就いて俸禄のみを得て、政務には携わらないという慣習ができた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, a plan was put out for making the Shinnou who were not able to become a Togu (crown prince) due to Emperor Kammu's policy a Minister for one of the eight central ministries, but later, from a viewpoint passive towards putting political responsibility on a Shinnou, it became custom for a Shinnou to take the position of an honorary office such as the Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Military (Treasury code), Ministry of Ceremonial, Danjoin, and Dazai no sochi, where they received only stipends and did not participate in state affairs.

In the Heian period, a plan was put out for making the Shinno, who was not able to become a Togu (crown prince) due to Emperor Kammu's policy, a Minister for one of the eight central ministries, but later, from a passive viewpoint towards putting political responsibility on a Shinno, it became a custom for a Shinno to take the position of an honorary office such as the Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Military (Treasury code), Ministry of Ceremonial, Danjoin, and Dazai no sochi, where they received only stipends and did not participate in state affairs.
sen.cmt: Shinnou のu を削除しました。were ⇒ was, who の前とpolicy の後にカンマを追加しました。viewpoint passive toward ⇒ passive viewpoint toward に訂正しました。became custom ⇒ became a custom
sen.e: In the Heian period, a plan was put out for making the Shinno, who was not able to become a Togu (crown prince) due to Emperor Kammu's policy, a Minister for one of the eight central ministries, but later, from a passive viewpoint towards putting political responsibility on a Shinno, it became a custom for a Shinno to take the position of an honorary office such as the Ministry of Central Affairs, Ministry of Military (Treasury code), Ministry of Ceremonial, Danjoin, and Dazai no sochi, where they received only stipends and did not participate in state affairs.

sen.j: この慣習に従い、政治実務から棚上げにされた人物の例として兼明親王がいる。
sen.e: An example of one person who, following this custom, was put aside from political affairs, was Imperial Prince Kaneakira.
An example of one person who, following this custom, was put aside from political affairs, was Imperial Prince Kaneakira.
An example of one person who, following this custom, was put aside from political affairs, was Imperial Prince Kaneakira.

tit.e: Imperial Princes of the Qing dynasty
Imperial Prince of the Qing dynasty
Imperial Prince of the Qing dynasty

sen.j: 清朝皇族愛新覚羅氏爵位の最高位。
sen.e: The highest rank in the Qing dynasty Imperial family Aishikagurashi peerage.
The highest rank in the Qing dynasty Imperial family Aishinkakura clan peerage.
The highest rank in the Qing dynasty Imperial family Aishinkakura clan peerage.

sen.j: 世襲親王と非世襲親王がある。
sen.e: There is the hereditary Imperial Prince and the non hereditary Imperial Prince.
There is the hereditary Imperial Prince and the non hereditary Imperial Prince.
There is the hereditary Imperial Prince and the non hereditary Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 世襲特権が認められているものには建国時期に活躍した6人の親王と2人の郡王のほかに、清朝中期、末期に特別な功績があるとして世襲が許された4人の親王がいる。
sen.e: There are 6 Imperial Princes and 2 guno (second highest rank of the court rank in ancient China) active during the nation-building time whose hereditary privileges were recognized, along with 4 Imperial Princes during the middle and later period of the Qing dynasty who were allowed heredity because of their great achievements.

Along with 6 Imperial Princes and 2 guno (second highest rank of the court rank in ancient China), who were active during the nation-building time and whose hereditary privileges were recognized, there are 4 Imperial Princes who were allowed heredity because of their great achievements during the middle period and the end of the Qing dynasty.
sen.cmt: Along with を文頭に移動しました。Active の前に, who were を追加し、whoseのフレーズをつなげました。during以降を最後部移動しました。中期、末期：middle period and the end of
sen.e: Along with 6 Imperial Princes and 2 guno (second highest rank of the court rank in ancient China), who were active during the nation-building time and whose hereditary privileges were recognized, there are 4 Imperial Princes who were allowed heredity because of their great achievements during the middle period and the end of the Qing dynasty.

sen.j: その他の非世襲親王は一代ごとに爵位が下がり、鎮国公まで下がってからは世襲になる。
sen.e: The other non hereditary Imperial Princes' peerage would go lower with every lifetime until he reached Chinkokuko, and from then it would be come hereditary.
The other non hereditary Imperial Princes' peerage would go lower with every lifetime until he reached Chinkokuko, and from then on, it would become hereditary.
sen.cmt: from then ⇒ from then on, be come ⇒ become
sen.e: The other non hereditary Imperial Princes' peerage would go lower with every lifetime until he reached Chinkokuko, and from then on, it would become hereditary.
